newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa signs maize accord of intent with Taiwan.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa signs maize accord of intent with Taiwan.

text.p: South Africa's Maize Board signed a long-term sales agreement of intent this week to sell maize to Taiwan until 1999, the Board's international marketing manager Giep Steenkamp said on Wednesday.
"The agreement was reached on Monday for the period May 1 1996 to April 30, 1999," Steenkamp told Reuters, adding that no quantities or prices had been set.
"It is an agreement of intent to do business," he added.
Steenkamp said in the past three years, the board exported around 50,000 tonnes of maize in total to Taiwan.
In the current season, the Maize Board had earmarked 1.5 million tonnes of maize for export to all destinations.
"We received 1.5 million tonnes of maize and there are quite of lot of (export) negotiations taking place," Steenkamp said.
South Africa's maize crop this year is estimated at 9.48 million tonnes, more than double the 4.405 million tonnes in the previous season.
Steenkamp said the Maize Board had already exported seven shiploads of maize -- a total of 242,235 tonnes -- this year, mostly to Iran.
Some white maize had also been shipped to South Korea and Venezuela, he said.
He said South Africa could have exported much larger quantities but exporters were hampered by congested facilities.
"We could have exported much more if we had the facilities but because we work with other exporters we had limited rail and harbour facilities," he added.
South Africa's maize marketing scheme was de-regulated this year. Under the new dispensation, the Maize Board was also responsible for issuing export permits to private traders.
Private exporters have been allocated 1.8 million tonnes of maize for exports in the current season.
Private traders have in total received permits to export 1.465 million tonnes of white and yellow maize.
Steenkamp said private traders had exported about 700,000 tonnes of maize so far this season.
